In 2022, Wage and Investment (W&I) Accounts Management separated income related identity theft from existing tax related and non-tax related identity theft procedures. The creation of this new IRM has been done in effort to deﬁne speciﬁc case processing guidelines for income related identity theft.
25.23.13-1, Paragraph for Income Related Identity Theft. Guidance formally found in IRM Self - Identiﬁed - Non - Tax - Related Identity Theft - IDT4.
The provisions in this manual apply to all divisions, functions units, employees, and contractors within the IRS working identity theft cases.
Table of Contents
Identity Theft
) Purpose: This manual provides case procedures speciﬁc to income related identity theft. In

, Wage and Investment (W&I) Accounts Management separated income related identity theft from existing tax related and non-tax related identity theft procedures. The creation of this new IRM has been in effort to deﬁne speciﬁc case processing guidelines for income related identity theft. (
) Audience: The provisions in this manual apply to all divisions, functions employees, and contractors within the IRS working identity theft (IDT) (
) Policy Owner: The owner of the policies contained herein is the Director, Accounts Management. (
) Program Owner: The Director of Accounts Management is the program owner. (
) Primary Stakeholders: The primary stakeholders are organizations that Accounts Management collaborates with; Return Integrity & Compliance Services (RICS), Compliance and Submission Processing. (

) Program Goals: • The development of short-term and long-term remedies to protect taxpayer information and make the experience of those who are victims faster and more efficient. • The development of Servicewide policy, procedures, and guidelines the priority of recognizing, marking and acknowledging individual taxpayer claims involving identity theft. • Support of Identity Protection Strategy and Oversight (IPSO) within the scope of programs associated with identity protection. (
) Employees in the Identity Theft Victim Assistance (IDTVA) organization Income Related Identity Theft (IDT) claims and respond to IDT victims. (
) Refer to IRM
, Servicewide Policies and Authorities, Policy for Customer Account Services Activities, for information. (

Audience: The provisions in this manual apply to all divisions, functions units, employees, and contractors within the IRS working identity theft (IDT) cases.
The development of short
term and long

term remedies to protect taxpayer information and make the experience of those who are already victims faster and more efficient. The development of Servicewide policy, procedures, and guidelines for the priority of recognizing, marking and acknowledging individual taxpayer claims involving identity theft. Support of Identity Protection Strategy and Oversight (IPSO) activities within the scope of programs associated with identity protection.
Employees in the Identity Theft Victim Assistance (IDTVA) organization process Income Related Identity Theft (IDT) claims and respond to IDT victims.

The Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) lists rights that already existed in the tax code, putting them in simple language and grouping them into 10 rights. Employees are responsible for being familiar with and acting in accord with taxpayer rights. See IRC 7803(a)(3), Execution of Duties in Accord with Taxpayer Rights. For additional information about the TBOR, see https://www. irs.gov/taxpayer-bill-of-rights.
Additional information is found in IRM 1.1.13.7.3, Accounts Management, and IRM 21.1.1, Accounts Management and Compliance Services Overview.

, Return Preparer Misconduct Victim Assistance Accounts Management Processing (
) Income related identity theft (IDT) occurs when a taxpayer’s TIN is used by someone else for income reporting purposes. Identity (

) Income related IDT is most commonly associated with the intentional misuse a taxpayer’s TIN to obtain employment. However, it can also include use of someone else’s TIN to claim gambling winnings, receive unemployment beneﬁts, or report any other type of income the TIN owner is unaware of sale of assets, cancellation of debt, etc.). (

) Income related IDT is considered non-tax-related because it does not impact the taxpayer’s tax account. However, income related IDT will be treated as related when tax administration is impacted. There must be an assessment refund issue on the taxpayer’s account to be considered tax-related. Income related IDT has the potential to negatively impact the taxpayer if left unre- solved. Review the list below for examples of common tax administration issues due to income related IDT. • Automated Underreporter (AUR) - Identiﬁed by a TC

(10-01-2022) Income Related Identity Theft - Determinations

For the year in question, was the occupation consistent with the er’s age (e.g., a minor child working as a truck driver)? Do all income documents available on CC IRPTR have the taxpayer’s correct name (e.g., spelling, last name, or entirely different name)? Do any income documents available on CC IRPTR reﬂect an address for the taxpayer that does not match the valid taxpayer’s current address or address history (e.g., different street address in the same city or different cities/states)?

If the income related IDT issue is IRS identiﬁed, and there is clear and con- vincing evidence to support making a determination, take the following actions:
Document the research you have completed in a CIS case note. Obtain lead/managerial concurrence with your determination. This must be documented in a CIS case note. Follow closing procedures in IRM
, Closing Income Related Identity Theft Accounts.

Related Identity Theft 25.23.13
25.23 Identity Protection and Victim Assistance
This Page Intentionally Left Blank
Exhibit 25.23.13-1 (10-01-2022) Paragraphs for Income Related Identity Theft

1) If the taxpayer is a victim of income related identity theft and unemployment compensation beneﬁts is an issue, manually send a Letter 4402C or Letter 4402SP closing letter using the selective paragraphs and ﬁll-in narratives listed in the charts below:
If Then CC IMFOLE shows IP PIN: 0 Select paragraphs “A”, “B”, “C”, “D”, and “E” CC IMFOLE shows IP PIN: 1 Select paragraphs “A”, “B”, “C”, “E”, and “F”

2) Use the ﬁll-in narratives listed below depending on the circumstances in the above chart. Capture the “request completed” screen on the CIS case. See IRM 21.5.1.5.1, CIS General Guidelines. Close the on AMS/CIS.
Note: You may use the paragraph below or similar

If Then use Selective Fill-in Number Open Paragraph Paragraph CC IMFOLE shows IP B 01 Your Form PIN: 0 14039 mentions an un- employment claim was ﬁled in your name without your knowledge. If you have not already done so, you should report this issue to your state’s employment agency and your employer. We highly recommend obtaining an Identity Protection Personal Identiﬁcation Number (IP PIN) to protect your account.
25.23 Identity Protection and Victim
Exhibit 25.23.13-1 (Cont. 1) (10-01-2022) Paragraphs for Income Related Identity

If Then use Selective Fill-in Number Open Paragraph Paragraph An IP PIN indicator is B 01 Your Form present on taxpayer’s 14039 mentions an un- account employment claim was ﬁled in your name without your knowledge. You should report this issue to your state’s employment agency and your employer if not already done. Our records indicate you are currently enrolled in the Identity Protection Personal Identiﬁcation Number (IP PIN) program. An IP PIN indicator is F 02 If you have previously present on taxpayer’s received a CP01A with account an IP PIN, you will continue to receive an IP PIN as usual. If you receive an IP PIN through the irs.gov IP PIN opt-in process, you will need to continue to request an IP PIN beginning mid-January each year prior to ﬁling your tax return.
